subtitles.text: Fai schifo cucinare, ja totalmente schifo!
Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara.
But this is not carbonara.
The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
That's how you know this isn't carbonara, because if you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
You see, bacon comes from a pig, whereas guanciale comes from a completely different animal, known as an Italian hog.
Oh my god, it looks like a jumping Italian horse!
You wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat, would you?
I really hope not.
Tigers are expensive.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
You can also do the back and forth, and whoops, maybe no forth.
Then make the traditional Italian egg white on toast as an appetizer.
Mmm.
This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.
It gets its name because the Romans who made it had huge pecs.
So did the goats.
They worked out together.
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.
So, whoop.
All right.
If I just maybe... okay, let's try.
Nope.
Hmm.
See, in my mind when I thought of this, none of the physics of how objects work would be an issue.
If you're Italian, you don't need to innovate in this department, because you simply harness the power of your hand gesture muscles, which makes this a breeze.
So grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.
Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.
And by go, I mean stay, because we're not done yet.
The original carbonara was made with handcrafted artisan spaghetti from the Veneto region.
Each spaghetti craftsperson had their signature style.
Sadly, these days you can only find straight parallel line spaghetti.
And you know, it just really angers me that the craft has been left to die like nobody cares.
Now, let's just fix that.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.
It sounds like an overreaction at first, but the crack sends a shock wave through the noodle, rendering it completely inedible.
I mean, look, here's uncracked spaghetti and cracked spaghetti.
If I didn't tell you that was spaghetti, you wouldn't have even recognized it.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Keep wang jangling that for the first bit to keep the spag from getting clingy.
By the way, spaghetti gets its name because you put it in the spa to cook it.
Now our bacon is cooked.
We're turning the burner off, waiting for this to cool, at least until there's no sizzle left, and a bit longer so we don't overcook the eggbased sauce.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting.
Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.

Since noodles are made of wheat, this is essentially a bacon sandwich, but if you do strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water, and if you get the kind of spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs, just pull those out and set them aside.

Then the sauce can go in, and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat, although you can put your pan on low to thicken it as well, because here comes more pasta water, making this nice and creamy.
The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
Here I'm trying to do that fancy twist thing, but it's not the right tool, and I don't know what I'm doing.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper, and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara.

If you want to really see not carbonara, here's an earlier attempt where I used whole egg, too much heat, and for some reason this came out way worse than my first attempt with whole egg, which came out great.
So are the whims of the food gods.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile, that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
It's a mysterious chemical reaction that only Italian scientists understand.
I'm craving carbonara, but I don't have guanciale.
Should I really even bother?
Oh no, will they judge my carbonara?
Because I want some cream upon it.
Should I eat it in the closet?
Oh no, what have I done?
I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetablefree.
They say it's no game.
Hang my head as I eat this not carbonara in shame.

steps: Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture and mix well.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
Add a small amount of pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon, mixing well.
Pour the egg yolk and cheese mixture over the spaghetti and bacon, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce.
If needed, add more pasta water to achieve the desired sauce consistency.
Finish with additional grated pecorino romano and black pepper before serving.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-1
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Prepare Meat: Slice the bacon or guanciale into small pieces or chunks in preparation for cooking.
outcome: Bacon is sliced into small pieces or chunks, ready for cooking.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop up some bacon into small pieces or chunks.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Bacon is used instead of guanciale to prepare the meat for the dish, although traditionally carbonara uses guanciale.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Using bacon instead of guanciale indicates that this is not a traditional carbonara recipe.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-2
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Prepare Egg Mixture: Separate egg yolks from whites, whisk them with whole eggs, and mix with grated Pecorino Romano or Parmesan cheese and black pepper.
outcome: A creamy egg mixture with cheese and pepper, ready to be combined with pasta.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Separate the egg yolks from the whites, whisk them together with whole eggs, then mix in grated Pecorino Romano or Parmesan cheese and black pepper.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The egg mixture forms the base of the sauce for carbonara, providing creaminess and flavor when combined with the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the 'hold the yolk with your thumb' trick to separate the yolks easily. Grate the cheese finely for better mixing.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-3
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook Pasta: Boil water, add salt, and cook the pasta until al dente, reserving some pasta water before draining.
outcome: Cooked spaghetti that is al dente
Reserved pasta water for sauce
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil water, add salt, and cook the pasta until al dente. Reserve some pasta water before draining.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta water is reserved because it contains starch that helps in binding the sauce and making it creamy.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Keep stirring the pasta initially to prevent it from sticking together. Make sure to reserve some pasta water before draining the pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Meat-4
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the sliced bacon or guanciale in a pan until crispy or golden, optionally adding garlic or olive oil for flavor.
outcome: Bacon is cooked and crispy or golden
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cook the sliced bacon or guanciale in a pan until it becomes crispy or golden.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Cooking the bacon or guanciale until crispy or golden enhances the flavor and texture, providing a savory and crunchy element to the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Optionally, add garlic or olive oil to the pan for additional flavor. Ensure the bacon is cooked evenly by stirring occasionally.

subgoal_summaries.title: Mix Egg and Cheese-5
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Mix Egg and Cheese: Add reserved pasta water to the egg and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese and prepare it for mixing with the pasta.
outcome: The cheese is melted and the mixture is ready to be combined with the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Add a bit of pasta water into the egg and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta water helps melt the cheese and prepares the sauce for mixing with the pasta, making it creamy.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Make sure the pasta water is hot enough to melt the cheese but not too hot to cook the eggs prematurely.
tools: Bowl for mixing the egg and cheese

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta and Meat-6
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine the cooked pasta with the cooked meat in the pan, mixing well and adding pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce.
outcome: The pasta is mixed with the bacon and a creamy sauce is formed.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Transfer the noodles directly from the water into the bacon pan and mix them well. Add the sauce and let the egg cook from the heat of the noodles. Add more pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The heat from the noodles will cook the egg in the sauce, and the pasta water helps to create a creamy texture.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water to use in the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-3
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook Pasta: Boil water, add salt, and cook the pasta until al dente, reserving some pasta water before draining.
materials: Spaghetti: 156 pieces of straight parallel line spaghetti.
outcome: Cooked spaghetti that is al dente and ready to be combined with the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Salt the boiling water and add 156 pieces of spaghetti. Stir initially to prevent sticking. Cook until al dente. Reserve some pasta water before draining.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta water is reserved to help emulsify the sauce and add creaminess when combined with the other ingredients.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Stir the spaghetti initially to prevent it from sticking together. Reserve pasta water before draining to use in the sauce.
tools: Pot: Used for boiling water and cooking the spaghetti.

subgoal_summaries.title: Add Egg Mixture-8
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Add Egg Mixture: Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the pasta and meat, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.
outcome: A creamy sauce coating the pasta and bacon
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the pasta and bacon, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The egg will cook just enough from the heat of the noodles, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs. You can put your pan on low to thicken the sauce if needed. Add pasta water to help make the sauce creamy.
tools: Pan for mixing pasta and sauce

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta and Meat-6
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine Pasta and Meat: Transfer the cooked pasta to the pan with the cooked meat, mixing well and adding pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce.
outcome: The pasta is combined with the bacon and sauce, resulting in a creamy dish.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Transfer the noodles straight from the water into the bacon pan and mix them well. Add the sauce and let the egg cook from the heat of the noodles. Optionally, put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce, and add more pasta water to make it creamy.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The heat from the noodles will cook the egg in the sauce, and the pasta water helps to create a creamy texture.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water. You can put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce if needed.

subgoal_summaries.title: Finish and Serve-10
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Finish the dish with additional grated cheese and black pepper before serving, optionally garnishing with crispy bacon or guanciale.
outcome: The dish is finished with a topping of grated cheese and black pepper, optionally garnished with crispy bacon or guanciale, ready to be served.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Finish with some pepper pepper pepper, and some more pecorino or parmesan.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Adding more cheese and pepper enhances the flavor and presentation of the dish, making it more appealing and closer to the traditional carbonara style.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the cheese is finely grated for even distribution. Use freshly cracked black pepper for the best flavor. If using bacon or guanciale as a garnish, ensure it is crispy for added texture.

steps: Slice half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Boil four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Mix the grated cheese into the egg mixture.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Turn off the heat under the bacon pan and transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with the bacon.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot spaghetti, stirring gently to avoid scrambling the eggs.
If needed, add a little pasta water to loosen the sauce and achieve a creamy consistency.
Plate the pasta and garnish with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-1
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Prepare Meat: Slice the bacon or guanciale into small pieces or chunks in preparation for cooking.
outcome: Bacon sliced into three-quarter inch pieces
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Take about a half pound of bacon and slice it into pieces about three-quarters of an inch thick.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Slicing the bacon into thick pieces allows it to render its fat slowly and become crispy, which is essential for the texture and flavor of the carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Thick cut bacon is preferred for better texture and flavor.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Meat-2
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the sliced bacon or guanciale in a pan until crispy or golden, optionally adding garlic or olive oil for flavor.
materials: Bacon (or guanciale) - thick cut preferred, about half a pound
Olive oil - optional, a tiny bit for cooking
outcome: Bacon is rendered and crispy, ready to be used in the pasta and as garnish
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn the pan on to medium heat. Add a tiny bit of olive oil if desired. Break the sliced bacon into the pan. Slowly render out the fat from the bacon, turning occasionally, until it is crispy. Take some bacon out for garnish and drain it on a paper towel. Turn off the heat and drain off most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Rendering the fat from the bacon and cooking it until crispy adds flavor and texture to the carbonara. Some of the bacon is used as a garnish for added crunch.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Be careful not to overcook the bacon. Turn the heat down towards the end to avoid burning. Drain the bacon on a paper towel to remove excess fat before using it as a garnish.
tools: Paper towel - for draining the bacon

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-3
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook Pasta: Boil water, add salt, and cook the pasta until al dente, reserving some pasta water before draining.
outcome: Spaghetti cooked to al dente
Reserved pasta water for later use
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt. Once the water is boiling, add the spaghetti and cook it for about 10 minutes until it is slightly al dente. Use tongs to remove the pasta from the water, leaving the water in the pot for later use.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta is cooked until al dente to ensure it has the right texture and will absorb the sauce well. Reserving pasta water is important as it can be used later to adjust the consistency of the sauce and help it emulsify.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use tongs to remove the pasta to avoid breaking it. Keep the pasta water simmering to use it later if needed to adjust the sauce consistency.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-4
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Prepare Egg Mixture: Separate egg yolks from whites, whisk them with whole eggs, and mix with grated Pecorino Romano or Parmesan cheese and black pepper.
outcome: A well-mixed egg and cheese mixture with a creamy consistency, seasoned with black pepper.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Separate two egg yolks from the whites and combine them with three whole eggs. Whisk the eggs together. Gradually whisk in the grated Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses until well combined. Add fresh ground black pepper to taste and whisk it into the mixture. Optionally, add a little boiling pasta water to the mixture and whisk quickly to equalize the temperature and loosen the mixture.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The mixture of whole eggs and yolks provides richness without being overly heavy. Whisking in the cheese creates a creamy texture that will coat the pasta. Adding black pepper enhances the flavor. Adding a bit of pasta water helps to equalize the temperature and prevents the eggs from scrambling when mixed with the hot pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a mixture of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano for a balanced flavor. Adjust the amount of black pepper to your preference. Adding a little pasta water to the egg mixture can help prevent scrambling when combined with the hot pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Meat-2
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the sliced bacon or guanciale in a pan until crispy or golden, optionally adding garlic or olive oil for flavor.
outcome: Bacon is crispy and golden
Rendered bacon fat is available for use in the pasta
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn the pan on to medium heat. Add a tiny bit of olive oil if desired. Break the sliced bacon into the pan. Slowly render out the fat from the bacon, turning occasionally, until the bacon is crispy. Once done, take some bacon out for garnish and drain it on a paper towel. Turn off the heat and drain off most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Rendering the fat from the bacon and cooking it until crispy adds flavor and texture to the dish. The rendered fat is used in the pasta to enhance its taste.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Be careful not to overcook the bacon. Turn the heat down towards the end of cooking to prevent burning. Drain the bacon on a paper towel to remove excess grease before using it as a garnish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-3
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook Pasta: Boil water, add salt, and cook the pasta until al dente, reserving some pasta water before draining.
outcome: Spaghetti cooked to al dente
Reserved pasta water for later use
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt. Once the water is boiling, add the spaghetti and cook it for about 10 minutes until it is slightly al dente. Use tongs to remove the pasta from the water, leaving the water in the pot for later use.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta is cooked until al dente to ensure it has the right texture and can absorb the sauce. Reserving pasta water is important as it can be used later to adjust the consistency of the sauce and help emulsify it.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use tongs to remove the pasta to avoid draining all the water, which is useful for the sauce. Be careful not to overcook the pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta and Meat-7
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine Pasta and Meat: Transfer the cooked pasta to the pan with the cooked meat, mixing well and adding pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce.
outcome: The pasta is coated in a creamy sauce made from the egg and cheese mixture without scrambling the eggs.
The sauce is emulsified with bacon fat and pasta water, creating a velvety texture.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with the rendered bacon fat. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta. Mix gently to avoid breaking the pasta and to ensure the eggs do not scramble. If the sauce is too thick, add pasta water to loosen it and create a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The heat from the pasta will gently cook the eggs, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling them. The pasta water helps emulsify the sauce, combining with the bacon fat and cheese to coat the pasta smoothly.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the heat is off when combining the pasta with the egg mixture to prevent scrambling. Use pasta water to adjust the sauce's consistency if it becomes too thick.
tools: Tongs for transferring and mixing the pasta
Pan for combining the pasta and sauce

subgoal_summaries.title: Add Egg Mixture-8
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Add Egg Mixture: Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the pasta and meat, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.
materials: Egg and cheese mixture (made from Pecorino Romano, Parmigiano Reggiano, whole eggs, and egg yolks)
outcome: A creamy sauce that coats the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot pasta and bacon, stirring quickly to ensure the eggs cook gently and form a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The heat from the pasta gently cooks the eggs, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling them. The mixture emulsifies with the bacon fat and pasta water to coat the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the heat is off when adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling. Stir quickly and gently to avoid breaking the pasta and to achieve a creamy texture. If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it.
tools: Tongs for mixing and serving the pasta
Pan for mixing the pasta and sauce

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta and Meat-7
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine Pasta and Meat: Transfer the cooked pasta to the pan with the cooked meat, mixing well and adding pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce.
outcome: The pasta is coated in a creamy sauce made from the egg and cheese mixture without scrambling the eggs.
The sauce is emulsified with the bacon fat and pasta water, creating a velvety texture.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with the rendered bacon fat. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta. Mix gently to avoid breaking the pasta and to ensure the eggs do not scramble. If the sauce is too thick, add pasta water to loosen it and create a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The heat from the pasta will gently cook the eggs, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling them. The pasta water helps emulsify the sauce, combining the egg mixture with the bacon fat for a smooth texture.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the heat is off when combining the pasta with the egg mixture to prevent scrambling. Use pasta water to adjust the sauce's consistency if it becomes too thick.
tools: Tongs for transferring and mixing the pasta
Pan for combining the pasta and sauce

subgoal_summaries.title: Finish and Serve-10
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Finish the dish with additional grated cheese and black pepper before serving, optionally garnishing with crispy bacon or guanciale.
outcome: The pasta is garnished with additional cheese and crispy bacon, enhancing its flavor and presentation.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: After plating the pasta, sprinkle additional Parmigiano Reggiano cheese over it. Then, add some crispy bacon on top for extra crunch and flavor.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Adding more cheese enhances the flavor and richness of the dish, while the crispy bacon provides a contrasting texture and additional savory taste.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the bacon is crispy before using it as a garnish to add a satisfying crunch to the dish.
tools: Cheese grater - for grating Parmigiano Reggiano

steps: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
Boil water for the pasta, adding a small amount of salt.
Twist the pasta and place it into the boiling water to prevent sticking. Cook for 8 minutes.
Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm thick pieces, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks.
Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high to render the fat.
Crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan with the guanciale to infuse flavor.
Crack black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to use the hotter inner part of the peppercorns.
Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.
Crack eggs into a bowl and add 20 grams of pecorino romano cheese. Whisk together.
Turn off the heat under the guanciale pan and add the cooked pasta directly from the pot, including some pasta water, to stop frying and start emulsifying.
Toss the pasta in the pan with the guanciale and fat, adding more pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, tossing quickly to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Finish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.

subgoal_summaries.title: Gather Ingredients-1
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Gather Ingredients: Collect all necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara, including bacon or guanciale, Pecorino Romano cheese, eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
materials: Guanciale - cured cheek of pork, salted, peppered, dried, and aged
Pecorino Romano cheese - sheep's cheese, crumbly, salty
outcome: All necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara are gathered.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Collect all necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara, including guanciale or pancetta, Pecorino Romano cheese, eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: These ingredients are essential for making an authentic Pasta Carbonara, which relies on the quality and combination of these specific items.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Try to get guanciale with the fat intact as it is needed for the dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-2
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook Pasta: Boil water, add salt, and cook the pasta until al dente, reserving some pasta water before draining.
outcome: Pasta cooked until al dente
Reserved pasta water
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Grab the pasta by two hands, twist it into the boiling water to prevent sticking, add a tiny amount of salt, and cook for eight minutes. Before draining, reserve some pasta water.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Twisting the pasta prevents it from sticking together. Adding only a tiny amount of salt is important because the cheese and guanciale are already salty. Reserving pasta water is crucial for emulsifying the sauce later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Twist the pasta as you add it to the water to prevent sticking. Use only a tiny amount of salt in the water.
tools: Tongs or pasta fork for handling pasta

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-3
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Prepare Meat: Slice the bacon or guanciale into small pieces or chunks in preparation for cooking.
outcome: Guanciale chopped into half-centimetre chunks
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Remove the skin from the guanciale, take a nice centimetre slice, and roughly chop it into half-centimetre chunks.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The guanciale is sliced and chopped to render the fat out effectively during cooking, which is essential for the flavor and texture of the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Try to get the guanciale with the fat intact, as the fat is needed for the dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Meat-4
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the sliced bacon or guanciale in a pan until crispy or golden, optionally adding garlic or olive oil for flavor.
outcome: Guanciale is golden and crispy
Fat is rendered out from the guanciale
Garlic flavor is infused into the fat
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Remove the skin from the guanciale and slice it into 1 cm slices. 2. Roughly chop the slices into 0.5 cm chunks. 3. Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high. 4. Add cracked garlic to the pan. 5. Cook until the guanciale is golden and crispy, and the fat is rendered out.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Starting with a cold pan allows the fat to render out slowly, which is essential for achieving the right texture and flavor. The garlic adds a subtle perfume to the dish as the fat renders out.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is cold before adding the guanciale to render the fat properly. Optionally, add garlic for extra flavor, but remove it before proceeding to the next step.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-5
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Prepare Egg Mixture: Separate egg yolks from whites, whisk them with whole eggs, and mix with grated Pecorino Romano or Parmesan cheese and black pepper.
outcome: A well-mixed egg and cheese mixture ready to be combined with pasta.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Crack the eggs into a bowl, add a little Pecorino cheese, and whisk them together.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Eggs are delicate and need to be treated carefully to avoid turning into scrambled eggs when mixed with hot pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Be time-sensitive when whisking the eggs and cheese to ensure a smooth mixture.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Meat-4
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the sliced bacon or guanciale in a pan until crispy or golden, optionally adding garlic or olive oil for flavor.
outcome: Guanciale is crispy or golden
Fat is rendered out of the guanciale
Garlic flavor is infused into the fat
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Start with a cold pan and turn it on to medium-high heat. Add the guanciale to the pan. Optionally, crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan. Cook until the guanciale is golden and crispy, rendering out the fat.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Starting with a cold pan allows the fat to render out slowly, which is essential for achieving the right texture and flavor. The garlic adds a subtle perfume to the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is cold before starting to render the fat properly. Optionally add garlic for extra flavor, but remove it before proceeding to the next step.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-5
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Prepare Egg Mixture: Separate egg yolks from whites, whisk them with whole eggs, and mix with grated Pecorino Romano or Parmesan cheese and black pepper.
outcome: A whisked egg mixture combined with Pecorino Romano cheese, ready to be added to the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Take a bowl and crack the eggs into it. Add about 20 grams of Pecorino Romano cheese to the eggs. Whisk the mixture together.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Eggs are delicate and need to be treated carefully to avoid ending up with scrambled eggs instead of a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Be time-sensitive when whisking the eggs and cheese to ensure the mixture is ready when needed.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Meat-4
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the sliced bacon or guanciale in a pan until crispy or golden, optionally adding garlic or olive oil for flavor.
outcome: Guanciale is crispy or golden
Fat is rendered out from the guanciale
Garlic flavor is infused into the fat
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Start with a cold pan and turn it on to medium-high heat. Add the guanciale to the pan. Optionally, crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan. Cook until the guanciale is golden and crispy, and the fat is rendered out.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Starting with a cold pan allows the fat to render out slowly, which is essential for achieving the right texture and flavor. The garlic adds a subtle perfume to the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is cold before starting to render the fat properly. Optionally add garlic for extra flavor, but remove it before proceeding to the next step.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta and Meat-9
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine Pasta and Meat: Transfer the cooked pasta to the pan with the cooked meat, mixing well and adding pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce.
outcome: Pasta is combined with guanciale and a creamy sauce is formed
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Drag the pasta and some of the pasta water into the pan with the cooked guanciale. Use the water to stop the frying and mix well. Add more pasta water as needed to emulsify the fat and water into a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta water and fat emulsify to create a creamy sauce, which is the desired texture for carbonara. The water stops the frying process, allowing the sauce to form.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the heat is off before adding the pasta to prevent frying. Add pasta water gradually to achieve the right consistency.

subgoal_summaries.title: Add Egg Mixture-10
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Add Egg Mixture: Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the pasta and meat, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.
outcome: A creamy sauce is created without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the pasta and meat, stirring quickly.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The creaminess is achieved through the emulsification of the cooking water and the fat, combined with technique and timing.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the heat is off before adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling. Stir quickly to create a creamy sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Finish and Serve-11
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Finish and Serve: Finish the dish with additional grated cheese and black pepper before serving, optionally garnishing with crispy bacon or guanciale.
outcome: The pasta carbonara is finished with a sprinkle of pecorino cheese and black pepper, ready to be served.
Optionally garnished with crispy bacon or guanciale for added flavor and presentation.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Finish the carbonara by sprinkling additional grated pecorino cheese and black pepper over the pasta. Optionally, garnish with crispy bacon or guanciale before serving.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Adding more pecorino cheese and black pepper enhances the flavor and presentation of the dish. The optional garnish of crispy bacon or guanciale adds texture and a savory element.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the cheese is finely grated for even distribution. Use freshly cracked black pepper for the best flavor. If using bacon or guanciale as a garnish, ensure it is crispy for the best texture contrast.

steps: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter.
Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks.
Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it releases fat.
In a bowl, beat two egg yolks.
Add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper to the egg yolks and mix.
Once the pasta is cooked, drain it and add it to the pan with guanciale, allowing it to cool slightly.
Mix the pasta with the egg mixture, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Stir until the sauce is creamy and coats the pasta.
Serve with additional grated parmesan or pecorino and a touch of pepper.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-1
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook Pasta: Boil water, add salt, and cook the pasta until al dente, reserving some pasta water before draining.
materials: Pasta (spaghettoni, the biggest size of spaghetti)
outcome: Pasta is cooked until al dente and ready to be mixed with the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil water and add salt in the ratio of 10 grams per liter of water. Once the water is boiling, add the pasta. Cook the pasta for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it is al dente. Reserve some pasta water before draining.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta needs to be cooked until al dente to ensure it has the right texture for the Carbonara. Stirring prevents the pasta from sticking together. Reserving pasta water can help adjust the sauce consistency later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Do not add oil to the pasta water as it is unnecessary and can prevent the sauce from adhering to the pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-2
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Prepare Meat: Slice the bacon or guanciale into small pieces or chunks in preparation for cooking.
outcome: Guanciale or pancetta cut into chunks, ready for cooking
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cut the guanciale or pancetta into chunks.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Cutting the meat into chunks allows it to cook evenly and release its flavors into the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use guanciale for a more authentic flavor, but pancetta can be used if guanciale is unavailable.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Meat-3
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the sliced bacon or guanciale in a pan until crispy or golden, optionally adding garlic or olive oil for flavor.
materials: Guanciale or pancetta (pork cheek or normal pancetta)
outcome: Crispy or golden guanciale or pancetta
Fat rendered from the guanciale or pancetta
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Put good olive oil in the pan, add the guanciale, and cook until crispy or golden.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Cooking the guanciale or pancetta renders the fat and makes it crispy, which adds flavor to the Carbonara sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you don't want too much fat, you can absorb some of it with a paper towel.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-4
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Prepare Egg Mixture: Separate egg yolks from whites, whisk them with whole eggs, and mix with grated Pecorino Romano or Parmesan cheese and black pepper.
outcome: A creamy egg mixture with cheese and pepper, ready to be combined with pasta.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Separate the yolks from the whites of the eggs, whisk the yolks with the whole eggs, add grated Parmesan or Pecorino cheese, and season with abundant black pepper.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The egg mixture forms the base of the Carbonara sauce, providing creaminess without the use of cream.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Do not add cream to the egg mixture as it is not part of the traditional recipe.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta and Meat-5
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine Pasta and Meat: Transfer the cooked pasta to the pan with the cooked meat, mixing well and adding pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce.
outcome: Pasta is coated with a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.
The dish achieves the desired creamy texture without using cream.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Transfer the cooked pasta to the pan with the cooked guanciale. Mix well and let it cool slightly to ensure the egg coats the pasta without scrambling.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta should not be too hot when combined with the egg mixture to prevent the eggs from scrambling, ensuring a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the guanciale is not too hot before adding the pasta to avoid scrambling the eggs. Stir gently to coat the pasta evenly.

subgoal_summaries.title: Add Egg Mixture-6
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Add Egg Mixture: Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the pasta and meat, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.
outcome: A creamy carbonara sauce that coats the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the pasta and meat, and stir quickly to create a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The mixture should be added when the pasta is not too hot to prevent the eggs from scrambling, ensuring a creamy texture.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pasta is not too hot when adding the egg mixture to avoid scrambling the eggs.
tools: Bowl for mixing eggs and cheese

subgoal_summaries.title: Finish and Serve-7
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Finish the dish with additional grated cheese and black pepper before serving, optionally garnishing with crispy bacon or guanciale.
outcome: The pasta carbonara is garnished and ready to serve, with a creamy texture and enhanced flavor from the cheese and pepper.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Sprinkle additional grated parmesan or pecorino cheese over the pasta. Add a touch of black pepper. Optionally, garnish with crispy bacon or guanciale.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The additional cheese and pepper enhance the flavor and presentation of the dish, making it more appealing and authentic.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pasta is not too hot when adding the final touches to prevent the cheese from melting too quickly and losing its texture.

subgoal_definitions.title: Gather Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Collect all necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara, including bacon or guanciale, Pecorino Romano cheese, eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
original_steps: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Meat
subgoal_definitions.description: Slice the bacon or guanciale into small pieces or chunks in preparation for cooking.
original_steps: Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks.
Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm thick pieces, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks.
Slice half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Chop bacon into small pieces.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Meat
subgoal_definitions.description: Cook the sliced bacon or guanciale in a pan until crispy or golden, optionally adding garlic or olive oil for flavor.
original_steps: Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it releases fat.
Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high to render the fat.
Crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan with the guanciale to infuse flavor.
Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Egg Mixture
subgoal_definitions.description: Separate egg yolks from whites, whisk them with whole eggs, and mix with grated Pecorino Romano or Parmesan cheese and black pepper.
original_steps: In a bowl, beat two egg yolks.
Add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper to the egg yolks and mix.
Crack black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to use the hotter inner part of the peppercorns.
Crack eggs into a bowl and add 20 grams of pecorino romano cheese. Whisk together.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
Mix the grated cheese into the egg mixture.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture and mix well.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Pasta
subgoal_definitions.description: Boil water, add salt, and cook the pasta until al dente, reserving some pasta water before draining.
original_steps: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter.
Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Boil water for the pasta, adding a small amount of salt.
Twist the pasta and place it into the boiling water to prevent sticking. Cook for 8 minutes.
Boil four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.

subgoal_definitions.title: Mix Egg and Cheese
subgoal_definitions.description: Add reserved pasta water to the egg and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese and prepare it for mixing with the pasta.
original_steps: Add a small amount of pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.

subgoal_definitions.title: Combine Pasta and Meat
subgoal_definitions.description: Transfer the cooked pasta to the pan with the cooked meat, mixing well and adding pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce.
original_steps: Once the pasta is cooked, drain it and add it to the pan with guanciale, allowing it to cool slightly.
Turn off the heat under the guanciale pan and add the cooked pasta directly from the pot, including some pasta water, to stop frying and start emulsifying.
Toss the pasta in the pan with the guanciale and fat, adding more pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce.
Turn off the heat under the bacon pan and transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with the bacon.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon, mixing well.
If needed, add a little pasta water to loosen the sauce and achieve a creamy consistency.
If needed, add more pasta water to achieve the desired sauce consistency.

subgoal_definitions.title: Add Egg Mixture
subgoal_definitions.description: Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the pasta and meat, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.
original_steps: Mix the pasta with the egg mixture, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Stir until the sauce is creamy and coats the pasta.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, tossing quickly to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot spaghetti, stirring gently to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Pour the egg yolk and cheese mixture over the spaghetti and bacon, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce.

subgoal_definitions.title: Finish and Serve
subgoal_definitions.description: Finish the dish with additional grated cheese and black pepper before serving, optionally garnishing with crispy bacon or guanciale.
original_steps: Serve with additional grated parmesan or pecorino and a touch of pepper.
Finish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.
Plate the pasta and garnish with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon.
Finish with additional grated pecorino romano and black pepper before serving.
